7.19.23  12:52 pm   Why do you think that books are kind of put on a higher "intellectual pedestal" than tv/movies?

     they are older. so they are a step or two higher up the formality chain. if you live long enough, you can indeed watch many of today's media formats get pedestalized just the same way, in comparison to whatever comes after

     I feel like there's a positive connotation regarding someone who reads a lot of books (well-read, learned, smart, etc.) whereas someone who watches a lot of tv/movies might be seen in a more negative light (tv/movies rot your brain, the person is lazy, etc.).

     ya, that notion rapidly becomes archaic

     I can imagine parents being mad at their kid for sitting around and watching tv or movies (or internet videos) all the time... but if the kid was reading books all the time, the parents would probably brag to all their other parent friends "Oh, Little Timmy is such a smart boy! He loves to read!"

     if anyone still actually thinks that (and i personally just assume no one does), the amount of levels on which that's archaic is mindboggling. among other things, it fails to account for the fact that 99% of reading is not done on paper books. younger generations in fact, in personal communications, tend to heavily favor the text message over the voice call. so who's reading now

     I think, at the core, books or movies or television or even video games... it's all just different forms/mediums of storytelling? I don't understand why one medium is considered intellectually superior to others?

     whatever's been established longer will be more firmly accepted at any given time. i imagine when books were first invented, they probably were often viewed as a corrupting and harmful influence on society

7.18.23  7:55 pm   Why is it that I can stand in front of at least tens of people, plus a camera, and sing to them without panicking but I am shaking at the thought of making a phone call. Like, what the fuck is wrong with me??

      it's because you are used to doing one, and not the other. if you make phone calls equally as often as you perform for people/cameras, then i think your level of anxiety would be the same for both

7.18.23  7:46 pm   important Q (can't seem to find the answer anywhere; lots of disagreement): what are sharps and flats called collectively? "accidentals?"

      that indeed is what they are called, when they are not in a key signature. so when you have to put them next to the notes as they occur, those are called 'accidentals'. Almost as if you....... 'accidentally' want a note that's not in the key signature, even though you surely did it on purpose. When it's in the key signature, set up at the beginning of the song, i don't think they are called accidentals. they are just called sharps and flats. With key signatures, sometimes i personally refer to adding or subtracting sharps or flats as 'degrees' to a key signature (in order of the circle of fifths), but that is probably not a widely accepted term for that, especially because it collides with other musical uses of the word degree

7.18.23  7:11 pm   at 7.17.23  10:15 am the link shows the question that it's referring to and also another question below it, is this on purpose

      it was probably not intentional that those 2 questions were asked within exactly the same minute. but, because they were, the link indeed does function correctly because it does not specify whether it refers to the first or second question from that time

7.18.23  7:07 pm   can you clarify from the question at 12:50pm what "bobfoolery" is?

      yes. the person provided the word 'tomfoolery' and i swapped 'tom' for 'bob'. the connection between the words 'tom' and 'bob' is they are both..... some dude maybe. Now that i think about it, it's possible that i was unintentionally influenced by an existing tom-bob swap that's already out there: tomcat==bobcat

7.18.23  6:13 pm   What would you consider the second chord of "a horse with no name" to be?

      it sort of ought to be Bmin7 with the bass player each time choosing where to go like a wandering horse in the desert. however, as i actually listen to it, i am mildly underwhelmed to find out that the bass just sticks to F# pretty much every time. also another small thing i notice about the actual recording is that there is high E string also during that chord, so therefore i suppose you can call it Bmin11 over F#. it's a real specific guitar voicing, so you might as well throw it on TAB in fact

7.18.23  6:00 pm   in what order generally did you record your zzja tracks? i'm loving stella by starlight at the moment!

      those were done on the date listed next to them. they are listed in chronological order, from botton to top

7.18.23  5:47 pm   i'm trying to learn how to play the acoustic guitar. do you have any advice for me?

      learn C, G, D, A, Emin, and Amin chords
